Impact of Martinez-Bodon v. Wilkie on Determinations Regarding Functional Impairment of Earning Capacity
The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims (CAVC), in
Martinez-Bodon v. Wilkie
, 32 Vet.App. 393 (2020), defined a disability under
38 U.S.C. 1110
as including any condition that results in a functional impairment of earning capacity.  CAVC clarified that this applies more broadly than to just pain.
CAVC, in
Martinez-Boden
, also held that a psychiatric condition must have a
Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders
, fifth version (DSM-5) diagnosis to constitute a disability, as
38 CFR 4.125
and
38 CFR 4.130
contain a DSM-5 diagnosis requirement for claimed psychiatric conditions.  The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit affirmed this holding in
Martinez-Bodon v. McDonough
, 28 F.4th 1241 (2022).
The
Martinez-Bodon
holding is not a liberalizing rule warranting application of
38 CFR 3.114
.
The
Martinez-Bodon
holding is dated August 11, 2020, and applies to all claims or legacy appeals pending or received on or after that date.
